Today is my favorite day of Spirit Week. For the uninitiated (I know there are a few of you out there), Wednesday is the day when each class wears their class color. Freshman are orange, Sophomores are red, Juniors are yellow, and Seniors are green. Not only is it not too difficult to dress appropriately, but it is also fascinating to see the patterns of students by grade. Since it's so easy to dress up, maybe 95% or so of everyone is school wears the appropriate colors, so it becomes clear what grade everyone is in. Some observations I made today: • At brunch, the crowd of people who hang out under the trees in the corner of the Quad by the English department is entirely made of Freshman. It was like this big orange blob today. Kinda freaky. • The majority of people who go across the street to Town and Country during the extended brunch on Wednesdays are underclassmen. This is especially odd if you consider the fact that Freshman were supposed to be at advisory at that time. • Most of the people in the MRC at lunch are juniors. Add that to the fact that most of them are also asian, and you being to wonder just how many asian junior (mainly boys) there are at my school. I mean, that place was crowded when I got there and the passing period had already started, so one can assume that a few of them had already left. It's kind of mind bloggling. • There are more juniors in my chem class than I thought there was. That is always another interesting part of color day. You have clear evidence of what grade specific people are in, and sometimes this can be very surprising. I think Gabrielle said that every year since she was a Freshman people are always surprised to see that she's not a Senior. • The "decky" half of the deck was the most colorful part on the quad... that I noticed. I wasn't looking too closely, but that's how it seemed to me. Of course, some of that was because there were some people who weren't wearing the appropriate colors. • My CS class is full of unspirited, slightly prickish nerds. Some of them are nice most of the time, but they're still prickish when it comes to Spirit Week. I could go into a rant, but suffice to say that I'm annoyed at many of them. On a side note, I'm inordinately pleased with myself because I got a lot of work done today. In CS I got all of our ("us" being Gabe and myself) helper classes for our semester project encoded, commented, and debugged (or at least, the syntax is right). Now all we need to do is write the driver class, which we have the pseudo for, and get all of the kinks out. Considering we have a good couple of months to do this, I think we're in good shape. Also, during 5th when I was TAing, I actually finished dealing with all of the relevant papers in 3 of the 4 math classes that I handle. Considering I have never caught up in any of them, I was terribly pleased with myself. Also, the 4th class shouldn't take too long to finish up either, and then I'll be entirely caught up! Maybe then I can finish my TA work during ther period I'm actually a TA and spend my prep doing thing other than grading papers (except once a week when I grade the Java programs, but that's a separate matter). What a refreshing thought...

I suppose I should comment on the fact that it's spirit week this week. Most of you know that, but I'm gonna jabber on about it anyway since there's nothing else to talk about. Today was definitely fun. Who doesn't love the idea of wearing a toga to school? Of course, the idea of wearing a toga is much better than the actual wearing of it. I definitely had to wrestle with it a number of times before someone finally helped me figure out a way to wear it that stayed in place sufficiently to get me to the end of the day, although it was definitely starting to slip a little at the end. Of course, the minor annoying details fade into the background in general. Sprit Week is fun, and that's all that matters, right? And hopefully our class won't emarrass ourselves horribly again this year by losing to the Freshman , never mind any of the other classes. I think last year we were just having an off year or something. Of course, I firmly uphold that we were punished unfairly for our dance. It kicked ass. Oh, and am I a big loser if I'm amused by our class shirt? "We don't take no croc!" hehe. It's funny cuz we're Crocodile Hunter. Or Dundee. I always get those two mixed up. Does it really make a difference? I think not.

Doing the reading is a pain in the ass, and we have these big projects that we have to do that are annoying too. *sigh* Is it June yet? Am I in college yet? God, I haven't even finished my application yet... *groans*

Tonight I watched my nephew Dwayne for a couple of hours so everyone else could go out and have a relaxing dinner, and he was a tired puppy. I'm just glad that he was the kind of tired that let me put Blue's Clues on an endless loop for about 4 hours and he would stay pretty satisfied, with only the occasional wandering off. Of course, that meant that I had to sit through Blues Clues for that long as well. God, I hate Blue's Clues... *grimace* If it weren't for the fact that I could use headphones to listen to music on my computer while I sat with him, I think I would have gone mad. I mean, not only are the episodes amazingly boring, repetative, and do-gooder (which isn't surprising because the show is aimed at toddlers), but the damn songs are horribly catchy! I mean, I was in the room while he watched an episode of it a couple of weeks ago, and the next day I had the "circle time" song stuck in my head for a while, and it wouldn't go away unless I drowned it out with other music. Anyway... yeah. That was my evening. *shrug* I have no life. Anyone want to do anything this weekend? Or actually, maybe not this weekend. I'm gonna need to buckle down and finish my application since it's due next Saturday. *wince* Also, there's Spirit Week. How the hell am I going to dress up for 80s day? Or Senior Citizen day? And I need to go find a toga and... God, I can't wait until this quarter is over and all of this is behind me .
I did 8 hours of homework tonight. That is all I have to say. Thank you, and goodnight .

It's funny, you know how people often have smells associated with people that they know well? You know, like the aftershave your father has always worn, or the fact that your grandparents' house always smells like grandma's cooking? I had never really noticed anything like that before with any of my relatives, but tonight as I was walking through the kitchen to put away my 2-in-the-morning-dinner remnants, I caught a whiff of something, and immediately knew that it was my mother's coffee, or coffee-like thing. I've never had any, but I know that she drinks it. I used to wake up in the mornings and see her drinking it as she read the newspaper, and I would sit on the couch and pick up the comics and I could smell this drink - whatever it was. I mean, it doesn't smell like coffee; it has this almost sickly sweet aroma to it, that I can't identify. I'm not sure if this is just how it smells, or if it tastes as sweet too. Anyway, it's kind of neat to think that I have a smell associated with a parent. Of course, I'm sure I have more, but this was the first one that I consciously realized. Maybe I'll pick up on others now that I'm more aware of their existence.

I must say that I actually had a lot of fun today, despite a misadventure or two. My day basically began with Jonathan calling me about hanging out, as we had arranged the night before. After a few rounds of telephone tag, because of silly parents (mine) and weird telephones (his), we made contact, and I went and got dressed and headed over to his house. We headed downtown, and wandered around being bored for a while, got some ice cream, and talked to some random Casti friend of his who I didn't know in Borders for a while. Oh, and I bought some new headphones, too. That was cool. After that we went over to Bun-Bun's to get him and go see The Laramie Project . However, we decided to take Jonathan's car, since the two of them were going to see the midnight movie afterwards, and I was not (stupid midnight curfew. Can I just say that I can't wait for my birthday? I hate the Cinderella clause) so we went over to Jonathan's house and traded my car for his, and headed over to Sacred Heart. The production was good, and we ran into lots of other cool people (Gabe, Kendal, etc.), since this was supposed to be a GSA trip. Also, Jonathan's friend urlLink Ingrid was there, who I hadn't really been introduced to, but had heard a bit about. Oh, and her friend Shane (sp?) was there too, and she was nice. The show was over around 10, and since that was 2 hours before midnight, which was everyone's next deadline, we decided to go hang out together elsewhere, and went to our respective cars to get there. When we got to our cars, it turned out that Gabe, being the fool that he is, had left his lights on during the show, and so his battery was dead. Also, no one there (there were three cars available) had any jumper cables, and so Ingrid and Shane took me to Jonathan's house to get my car, since I did. That was fun, though, since I got to know them better and such. They're definitely cool chicks. Of course, once we got back to Sacred Heart, we all realized that no one knew how to use jumper cables, and since we knew enough to know that mistreating them tended to blow things up, and none of us wanted that, I called my dad and had him explain to me how to use them. That was definitely difficult until we discovered the flashlight that my mother had left in my car from when she used it (bless you, mother) so we could figure out which part of the battery was positive, and which negative (hence, no explosions). Then we got the cars started without anything going boom, and headed off to Jonathan's en masse. We hung out there for about half and hour, before those of us with midnight curfews went home, and those going to the midnight movie went there instead. Overall, I'd say the day was a success, especially since I feel like we never do anything on the weekend. I say that we should have similar adventures in the future. Or at least, we should go out and do something. Anyone else agree with me? Especially when our other friends don't have the PSATs in the morning and feel that they can join us as well. Silly juniors, don't you understand that you need to relax on the weekends as a counterbalance to the insanity that is your lives? Trust me, I was just there.

Okay, this is one of the funniest conversations I've had on AIM to date, and it's all because of some miscommunication (which is ironic, if you think about it). I sent a message to Jonathan's mother (yes, I know her screen name) to try to find out what time he would be getting home tonight, and this is what happened (FYI for the uninitiated: Jonathan's mother's name is Susan, his father is Jack, and his sister is Eleanor): me (5:36:06 PM): what time is Jonathan getting home today? Susan's sn (5:36:29 PM): flight gets in at 8:50 Susan's sn (5:36:33 PM): And this is your father. Susan's sn (5:36:36 PM): (snrk) me (5:36:39 PM): what?!? Susan's sn (5:36:51 PM): confuse-a-kid strikes again. me (5:37:02 PM): now I'm doubly confused me (5:37:03 PM): what's going on? Susan's sn (5:37:20 PM): Well, I was in the office and your mother isn't home yet. me (5:37:42 PM): wait, *who* isn't home yet? me (5:37:49 PM): is this Jack? Susan's sn (5:37:57 PM): YOUR MOTHER isn't home Susan's sn (5:38:10 PM): I identified myself as your father. me (5:38:16 PM): yes, but... Susan's sn (5:38:18 PM): Susan will have to judge whether I'm Jack Susan's sn (5:38:31 PM): I believe we are the same person me (5:38:39 PM): uh, right Susan's sn (5:39:13 PM): So this is Jack, Susan isn't home yet, and Jonathan should arrive home sometime between 9:30 and 10:00 tonight, if his flight's on time. me (5:39:21 PM): check me (5:39:22 PM): gotcha me (5:39:32 PM): it was the father/mother part that confused me there... Susan's sn (5:39:51 PM): Oh..... Susan's sn (5:39:55 PM): This isn't Eleanor me (5:39:58 PM): no me (5:40:01 PM): this is Elizabeth Susan's sn (5:40:01 PM): No wonder! Susan's sn (5:40:06 PM): Of course. Susan's sn (5:40:13 PM): Sorry about that me (5:40:17 PM): s'alright Susan's sn (5:40:24 PM): I just assumed it was Eleanor, withoug looking me (5:40:34 PM): yeah, I guess that's understandable me (5:40:35 PM): :-) Susan's sn (5:40:47 PM): It's been confusing for Eleanor when I answer on Susan's machine Susan's sn (5:40:52 PM): So I was playing that up me (5:40:57 PM): ah ha Susan's sn (5:41:08 PM): Though i did think she was being a bit dense Susan's sn (5:41:30 PM): which she would have been had she not been you me (5:41:36 PM): exactly Now, while I do consider Jack and Susan to be parental-figures to me, I don't immediately think of them when someone says "your mother" or "your father". Go figure...

Okay, so I'm not sure if all of you know that I go to church, but I do. Also, my church seems to go through an astounding number of organists, for a reason that I do not fully understand. Anyway, our current organist, who is cool, is moving back East to work at his dream job and so they had this big hunt to find a new organist over the summer. One of the candidates stayed at our house while they interviewed him (while I was at NYLF), and we overlapped by a few days so I got to meet him. My initial reaction was that he was a big nerd, and since this was directly after coming back from a technology convention if I can say that, suffice to say, he was nerdy. However, the nerdiness of an organist isn't actually all that important to churches, and I guess he was the best candidate or something, because they hired him as the replacement and he's in the process of moving here from... wherever the hell he came from. Now my mother, being the all-too-kind soul that she is, allowed him to stay here again while his stuff was being shipped. So he has been around the house all weekend, and it has been grating on my nerves. Not only is he just a big nerd, but he's also really loud . I don't think he really understands the concept of changing voice levels for different situations. Thank god he'll be out of here by tomorrow afternoon. Sorry, end rant.

Color me nervous. I am about to go to my MIT interview, in hopes of not making a complete fool of myself. Of course, they say that if the interview goes badly, they'll just disregard it, but still... Wouldn't a really good interview be nice? Of course, I was also being thrown all over the place this morning when I was getting ready to go. As I started getting dressed, the first song I heard was Jimmy Eat World's The Middle . Now, I'm not a superstitious person, to say, except when things point towards something good. So, when the cheerfull sound of their lyrics floated over to me, I relaxed a little. I mean, think about it: Hey Don't write yourself off yet It's only in your head you feel left out Or looked down on Just try your best Try everything you can ... Everything, everything will be just fine Everything, everything will be all right, all right ... Live right now Just be yourself It doesn't matter if that's good enough For someone else Of course, a few songs later, the radio decided to wrench me in the other direction with some... less peppy songs. Pariticularly of the you're not going to do well so don't even try variety. I'm blanking on specifics at the moment (I must have blocked them out), but suffice to say, I changed the station. And then the person I'm interviewing with called to say she would be late, and so here I am, trying to stall for half an hour until it's time to leave.

Yesterday I saw the music video for Good Charlotte's Hold On , which was also the first time I had heard the song (or at least the first time I paid attention to lyrics and such), and it gave me chills. It's not even like I knew Benjamiin Tachibana, or any of his family, or even Steven Wertheimer, and yet... why? Why did they feel the need to do it? And why is it affecting me like this? And of course, Hold On makes me think of the Buffy episode Earshot as well. As Buffy says, "You know what? I was wrong. You are an idiot. My life happens to on occasion suck beyond the telling of it. Sometimes more than I can handle. But it's not just mine. Every single person down there is ignoring your pain because they're too busy with their own. The beautiful ones, the popular ones, the guys who pick on you. Everyone. If you could hear what they were thinking -- the loneliness, the confusion. It looks quiet down there, but it's not. It's deafening."

So my mom's parents, her brother John, his wife Nancy, and their adopted son Brian are all visiting for Thanksgiving. It's definitely odd to see them, since I hardly ever do. I feel kind of bad about how disconnected I am from my mom's side of the family, but they all live so far away! Most of my father's brothers and sisters (and their kids) live here, as does my paternal grandmother, so I see them a lot more often than I do my mother's family. Also, the Reids (my dad's family) all very engergetic, lively, personable and interesting people, so whenever we do get together, we're having fun and doing stuff. However, my mother's family is a lot more... toned down, I guess. I mean, I don't feel that I have as much in common with them as I do with my dad's family, and so we don't have as much to talk about. Also, they aren't necessarily really chatty, so awkward silences aren't in a terribly short supply. Heck, I keep on going back and forth between thinking that Nancy doesn't like me particularly, and that she does. It's all very confusing. Also, their son Brian is 8, and I had only met him once before he got here, and that was only for an afternoon. So not only is he less than half my age, he also doesn't know me, and I have to constantly edit what I say around him (he's still in the "I am being taught to be a 'good boy', so I am not supposed to swear, be a bad sport, cheat, etc." stage (we were playing cards)). Altogether, this means that things while they are here are a little... strained, I guess. Now all I can do is see how the rest of the weekend plays out. Oh, and Happy Turkey Day! :-)

I thought I would post this, just because. I don't take quizzes very often, since they're usually very transparent, but this one was maybe a 7 on a scale from 1-10. Of course, the final determining factor: is it true? You are Form 0, Phoenix: The Eternal. "And The Phoenix's cycle had reached zenith, so he consumed himself in fire. He emerged from his own ashes, to be forever immortal." Some examples of the Phoenix Form are Quetzalcoatl (Aztec), Shiva (Indian), and Ra-Atum (Egyptian). The Phoenix is associated with the concept of life, the number 0, and the element of fire. His sign is the eclipsed sun. As a member of Form 0, you are a determined individual. You tend to keep your sense of optomism, even through tough times and have a positive outlook on most situations. You have a way of looking at going through life as a journey that you can constantly learn from. Phoenixes are the best friends to have because they cheer people up easily.

In the further adventures of Elizabeth's locker... Today I decided I was sick of looking at the message on my locker, so during my prep I decided to go hunt down someone to try to get them to clean it off. However, first I went to my locker to drop off some books, since I hadn't had a chance to earlier in the day. Guess what I saw when I got there? That's right! My locker was once again lost among the masses, profanity-free. Anyone else find it ironic that it got cleaned off the day that I decided to find someone to clean it for me? Not that I really mind, since it saved me work, but still...
I'm sorry, urlLink this just blows my mind!
I just added a page with some of the pictures that I took around school this week. Please peruse them at your leisure.

I think I must have the only locker in school with graffiti on it already . I mean, we've only had them for about 2 or 3 weeks now, and I've only been using mine for about 3 of those days (total). When they gave out locker assignments, I went to my locker and put my lock on it, and then promptly forgot which locker was mine. When I finally had time to hunt down where the list was kept in the office, it was Tuesday of this week. I headed over to it to check to make sure that it was really there and that I knew my combination, and when I arrived I was welcomed by the lovely sight of " F*ck you c*nt! Die! " in bright blue permanent ink. Now, considering no one else knew which locker was mine, and I couldn't think of anyone who would feel the need to say this to me, never mind in permanent blue ink for all the school to see, I just assumed that it was a random (and extremely rude) tagging — probably from an underclassmen. However, when I returned to my locker on Thursday, I discovered a new message below it from a red ball-point pen reading, "Never!" I guess this means that two people who I don't know are having anargumentt/insult fest on my locker. Why they decided to do this on my locker I couldn't tell you. I also couldn't tell you who was doing it, although I sure do wish I could... Anyway, I'm not sure if I should just ignore it and hope no one gives me any funny looks while I'm transferring my books to and from my locker or if I should try to have someone remove it. Oi.

Triskaidekaphobia. How many people have we heard of with this rather odd disease? We see it in movies, hotels, and old fairy tales. It strikes when you least expect it, and among people of all intelligences. Maybe you suffer from this malady yourself, who knows? And what is the meaning of this mouthful? Fear of the number 13. Cower in fear!!! Who could resist such a cool name? I want Triskaidekaphobia!

Well, I meant to post this last night, but Blogger wouldn't let me so I thought I would do it now. Last night I broke down and spent about an hour going through the "Insider's Guide to the Colleges" to try to figure out where in the world I'm going to apply. It was, as I always insisted it would be, not very helpful at all. Of of the schools sounded exactly the same , and I had to revert to checking to see what types of majors were most common, what the SAT scores were, and as a final reality check I would skim a few paragraphs or the titles of subsections. All in all, I'm about where I was before I opened the book. I know I'm applying to Amherst and Carnegie, and I'm pretty sure I'm going to apply to Williams, RIT, Rensselaer, and WPI, although those last three are all kind of the same, and kind of boring, but okay as backup schools, I guess. Oh, and I might apply to Harvard, I'm not sure yet. I feel vindicated in my belief that such books are stupid and of almost no assistance, except in the way that they have a complete list of all of the colleges and helpfully organize them by location, which is a large part of my decision. A random question popped in my head tonight, and now it's bugging me. If anyone could tell me the answer, I'll... give them a hug! Of course, depending on their location, it could turn out to just be a cyber-hug, but the principle is the same. Anyway, here's the question: How did they come up with Fahrenheit? I mean, Celsius was obviously created from the freezing and boiling points of water, and Kelvins are like Celsius only off by 273 so that it accurately represents absolute zero as zero, but where in the world did they come up with our Fahrenheit system? Anyone know?

I don't know how I survive Christmas each year. I only started going out to shop today. I started at 5pm. I finished at 6pm, and that included going to the bank and getting gas. How do I do this? , you might ask. It's simple, really. I only need to buy presents for 5 or 6 people each year, because I'm too lazy/horrible/don't think ahead enough to get presents for most of my friends. Also, my oldest sister Allyson is the organized one, and knows I "hate" to shop (I don't actually hate it, but I let this story perpetuate because I never know what to get anyone), so I just give her money and she deals with stocking stuffers and presents for my father and my step-mom. And since each year I have to buy a present for one of my three siblings (we have a drawing so we don't have to buy for everyone each year... the same goes for my extended family... but I'm getting ahead of myself) and this year I drew Nick (my one and only brother), Victoria (my step-mom, his mom) knew I didn't know what to get him and ordered sunglasses for him online for me, so all I needed to do was give her money. As for my cousin Garrett (the person I drew in the extended family drawing), I asked him what he wanted and he requested a laser pointer, and I, being the stingy and realistic person that I am, remember that I, too, had gone through a laser pointer stage and still had one of my old ones in rather nice condition, and since a good laser pointer would be somewhat out of the family drawing price range, I could just get some new batteries for it and give it to him instead. Furthermore, my mom hardly ever wants anything that requires buying (for example, this year she wants Vanessa and me to make her cds with music that she "would be unhappy not to recognize when they're on the oldies station in 40 years" *sigh* (don't get me started...). So that just meant I had to go buy some blank cds with jewel cases, to be burned tomorrow. Oh, and while I was there I picked up Shannon's present (yes, you know what it is, Shannon) since we always get presents for each other (feel special, dammit!). And thus, I managed to survive Christmas once again with little or no shopping. Is it wrong of me to feel guilty for this? I think the hardest part was finding the right kind of batteries for the laser pointer. I think I cheated Christmas.

Until tonight, I hadn't seen my nephew, Dwayne, for a few days. I think the last time I saw him was Monday or Tuesday, and since then I swear to god he's learned to speak in sentences. It's crazy. I mean, he could speak before, and he had a few phrases down ("auntie's car", "bye bye, dada", etc.), but tonight when I saw him he was jabbering away, "Bella has my ball", "Let's look at the pictures", "That's auntie's", "Bella is eating crackers". It was pretty mind-blowing. I mean, he's still talking in baby-talk, so you have to look past the lack of r's and s's and whatnot, but the sentences are definitely there. It's crazy. *sniff* They grow up so fast. I can't wait until we can have actual conversations! Of course, that means we'll be getting into the "why?" stage...

Okay, this is a question for those of you who drive (or maybe just those of you who think). When you are driving and you want to turn left, but there are two left turn lanes, which do you prefer to go into? Because I have observed a strange phenomenon that makes me think that most drivers are complete idiots. There is a left turn such as I described that I take every day on my way home from school, and every day , there are more cars in the rightmost left turn lane, and if a new car is just arriving, it is much more likely to go to the right lane rather than the left, even if there are more cars in the right lane. Now, this might make some sort of sense if the right lane were inherently faster, but it's not . In fact, cars in the left lane have to travel less distance, and so actually go faster than the right lane, so why does this happen? Any thoughts?

Today in Sociology, which is (somewhat surprisingly) turning out to be one of my favorite classes, we were discussing social classes in America. Have you noticed how the large majority of people here in the United States refer to themselves as "middle class"? It's crazy. But I digress. The real reason I'm here is to talk about me (sort of). We just finished watching this really interesting video about social classes, and the last part of it was about a high school in Austin, Texas, where the different social groups were very clearly delineated. The obvious parallel was that this high school was much like Paly, which people had already pointed out. However, that is always been something that has confused me about our school (and high school in general, I guess). Cliques. I just don't see them as being as all-powerful as they are always portrayed as being in high school. I mean, whenever people ask me what social groups there are at Paly, I am basically just like, "Um... well, there are the... people. And they... hang out, I guess." In other words, I don't really feel that our high school is entirely broken down into independent groups that function separately from each other. I mean, sure there are groups that tend to be a bit isolated and unwelcoming to outsiders (the people on the benches or by the Student Center being the main ones), but overall I don't really feel that I could pick a person and tell you specifically what "clique" they are a member of. Anyway, I mentioned this to Mrs. Soutter (my teacher) while we were having group discussions, and she proceeded to give me what I feel is one of the better compliments I've ever received. She said (something along the lines of) that because I was such an understanding person, I was friends with people from all possible social groups and I did not view people through the lens of their social statuses. While that doesn't really sound like much when I put it here, the way she said it at the time made me feel really... good. I wish I could remember exactly how she phrased it. It made me feel all warm and fuzzy inside. I just hope it doesn't go to my head...

Okay, here's a story, with some details withheld to help defend against my own embarrassment, because I know some of you know to whom I am referring (well you don't know in the sense that you know who I'm talking about, but you do actually know them... I'm just gonna stop talking here and get on with the story. You know what I'm trying to say... right?). So there is this person who we'll call X, for lack of a singular gender-neutral pronoun. I greatly admire X. I think that X is intelligent, funny, nice, and cool. However, I don't have any real excuses to talk to X, so when I see X online, I know that if I were to try to talk to X our conversation would be pointless, and pointless conversations online drive me bonkers, and I do not want to inflict that upon X, in fear of making X dislike me (or like me less, possibly... hard to tell). (Wasn't that a lovely long sentence? ...but I digress. More.) However, today I was discussing my great admiration for X with some other people who I knew admired X as well (long story...) and they said that I should just tell X how I feel, not in the "tell him you like him!" sense... especially considering we don't even know if X is a boy, and we do know that I don't have a crush on X. This is strictly in the "I really admire you and think you are amazingly cool. I just wish I had more things to talk to you about. Now that I am done completely embarrassing myself, I'm gonna shut up now." At least, that was how I pictured the conversation going. So anyway, when I got home tonight, I got online and saw that X was signed on! So I gathered my courage, and initiated contact... but it turns out they weren't actually there! And now the longer I wait to do this, the more I think I'm going to lose my courage... Anyway, there was no real point to this story. I just felt the need to share this potentially horribly embarrassing story with you all...

Okay, I've come to a conclusion. Senior year is harder than junior year, I don't care what anyone says. Or at least, I know it's true for me. Junior year is just a lot of work, but it's all doable. One might even call it busywork, but it's not quite tedious enough for that. Senior year, on the other hand, has fewer classes, I admit. However, the classes that you do have that are hard are hard . I mean, I only have 2 hard classes, but they're insanely difficult. Between AP Chem and BC Calc, I have more tests than I can make myself study for, more things to memorize than I could even if I were able to memorize stuff, and worse grades than any of my classes before. Ever. Well, more chemistry than calculus. So really this rant is mainly about chemistry, but calculus is included too because it's fucking hard and I get fucking confused too easily. This made so much sense last year. Hell, when we did the same material last year, it made sense, and when we did it this year, it didn't. In summary, lots of work sucks, but getting demoralized because you can't do the work you have been given is 10 times worse. At least.

Want to know how I spent my morning? Complimenting random people downtown. Yes, that's right, that was the only reason I was there. Well, technically I got some food while I was out, but that's beside the point... So for Mr. Hanmer's World Classics class, we had this project that we had to do called "Chivalry is Not Dead". For this project, we had to go out and do some random chivalrous act - planned or otherwise - and write about society's reaction to it, as well as our own. So this morning Shannon, Sandy, and I went downtown and just walked around complimenting people. For the most part, no one really had a very strong reaction, but there was this little old lady standing outside of Longs holding a few flowers, which I duly complemented her on. She said that she had gotten them from a "public corner" (whatever the hell that is), and gave them to me. Being most pleased with my new flowers, I later encouraged Sandy to give them to another little old lady who we saw, who was sitting alone at a table, reading the newspaper. She seemed rather pleased with the flowers as well, so overall I felt that our adventure was a success.

You know, I'm not sure if Mr. Hanmer's teaching style has changed since I was a Freshman or if it's just because I've had more experience in different English classes, but I'm really not enjoying his class this time around. I mean, I feel like he has his opinions about the book and the characters, and while he seems to encourage people's opinions on subjects, he only agrees with certain ones (even if he doesn't say anything... this is just a feeling I get). Also, he keeps on rambling on about how the "book reads you", which I understand, but he keeps saying it after I point anything out, which is a bit annoying after a while. Especially since I feel like he's saying that because he doesn't agree with me, even if other people express similar opinions. Also, he really loves to insult math and science. I understand that he's an English teacher, so he doesn't necessarily excel at them, but does that mean that he has to insult them at every turn? I don't insult English just because it isn't my favorite subject! I'm not even sure if what I just said makes it sound like how I feel things are going, but it really is starting to irk me... and it's only been like 2 weeks. I mean, there are good things about that class, but still... Grr. Oh, and oddly enough, I had quite a nice conversation with Dr. Nick (of all people) today in the MRC. It was kind of random, but she was very reassuring of the fact that it's not just the students who are afraid of Mrs. Lawrence... I don't know, there was more to it than that. Anyway, it was strangely nice talking with her. Even if she was being he usual, extremely talkative self...

So, generally I have gotten remarkably respectable grades over the years, with the exception of Spanish, which still wasn't too bad. My parents have always left me to my devices and been proud of me, etc. This year I pulled off respectable grades by the skin of my teeth (which I had already mentioned), so I was very pleased with myself. However, my grades arrived today and my dad asked, "what did you do to get a B- in chem?", and by that he meant, "what went wrong?" I'm not sure why I was so put out by that. I mean, that class is hard , and he was basically wondering what I did wrong to get an A. I guess I've just been taking my parents' chillness about grades for granted until now, because I've always gotten good ones. Of course, I could just be seriously over reacting and over analyzing what he said, because I'm very, very, very tired.
My dad just got a new G5. *drools*

I'm leaving on Friday to go to England over Spring Break to visit my sister (excitement!), and I realized today that I didn't want to lug all of my CDs around like I used to have to, because I didn't need to. Thanks to the glory of a 40GB iPod, I can carry all of my music in a very small space. Of course, first I needed to get all of my music onto my computer. I have all of these CDs sitting around that I had never really bothered to rip before, since I usually had some of the songs on my computer already, or I was too lazy, or I just forgot. So all evening I've been sitting in front of my computer and going through my CDs and ripping the ones that I hadn't ripped already. It's actually rather a lot of work but definitely worth it, I think. Man, I had forgotten how good some of this stuff was.

Okay, so I couldn't resist doing one of these "Song Memes" to which urlLink MacKenzie introduced me (and many other people): The Idea and The Rules * You have a name. * Spell your name out with song titles. * Use each artist only once. * Use each song only once. * This is pretty damn simple, people. * Once again, make your mix under 80 minutes for a bonus. Depending on the length of your name, 160. * For a supermegaextra bonus, use only song titles that include names. * Have fun. So this is mine (there's a list without my comments at the bottom if you want to jump straight there): 1. Every Morning - Sugar Ray (3:45) This was the first music video I can ever remember watching, and the first song I heard on the radio where I knew all of the words. 2. Let Me In - Save Ferris (6:14) This song just rocks. It's that simple. It's beautiful. Definitely my favorite Save Ferris song (10 Things notwithstanding). 3. I Know - Fiona Apple (4:55) I subconciously picked up an affinity for many artists because of my sister, who has excellent taste in music (hi, Vanessa). Fiona Apple was one of them. She would play her Fiona Apple CDs, and I would hear them as I was going to sleep, and years later when I started listening to music myself (I was, quite sadly, rather a late bloomer in that department, but we'll get to that later) I rediscovered them while having the advantage that I already loved them, so I still have a soft spot for Fiona Apple, among others. 4. Zombie - Cranberries (5:06) My favorite Cranberries song might be Dreams (it's debatable), but this song is quite excellent as well. Besides, how many songs do you know that start with a Z? 5. Almost Blue - Gwen Stefani (2:59) This is the first song I heard that made me realize just how amazing Gwen Stefani's voice is. No Doubt is an amazing group, but sometimes I feel that her voice isn't stressed as much as it could be because of all the other things happening in their songs (not to say that she doesn't use her voice well in those, but you get distracted from the richness of it). Also, I think I downloaded this well before I thought to download any of No Doubt's songs, and it has such a different feel to it that it's always stuck out in my mind as being just Gwen. 6. Beautiful - Christina Aguilera (3:58) This is the song that made me respect Christina Aguilera. While I enjoyed Genie in a Bottle, I had tried to avoid the pop scene as much as possible for quite a few years, but when I heard this I realized I was being silly for doing so on principle. She also has a gorgeous voice (I don't think I could stress that enough), and this song is beautiful both in the way it sounds, and what it says. Rock on, Christina. 7. Everything in its Right Place - Radiohead (4:09) This song is cool. Radiohead is a cool band. There were quite a number of their songs I could have chosen for this mix, but I chose this one mainly for its strategic value (it took me a long time to figure out which songs I wanted to choose by which artist to make things fit as nicely as I could), although it's also here in its own right. 8. Thank You - Alanis Morissette (4:18) Alanis Morissette has good music. This is one of her good songs, and one that even I picked up on when I wasn't listening to any music in particular. I think I might have Vanessa to thank for that again, but I'm not sure. Either way, I've always liked Alanis Morissette, as well as this song. 9. Hailie's Song - Eminem (5:23) I love this song. I do. I mean, there are other Eminem songs that I like as well, but he's actually singing here! And it's a good song. What more need be said? 10. Gangsta's Paradise - Coolio (4:01) Another song from my early childhood. I'm thinking my brother Nick is to thank for this one, but I could be wrong. This song is excellent. It crosses a number of genres, in my opinion, and it never really gets old. I've liked it as long as I can remember (although sticking this in here does make me wish that I had a "W" in my name, for Waterfalls by TLC, but that's another matter...). 11. Like The Rose - B*Witched (3:56) I think it was the summer after sixth grade that I first began entering the music world in my own right. However, I kind of pushed myself into it and so I didn't have a chance to get my bearings before I bought 3 or 4 CDs. While most of them were only okay, or blatantly sucky, one of the ones I got was B*Witched's self-named first CD, and dammit I liked it! I still do, actually. Mock me if you will, but I'll stand by it. Anyway, this was my favorite song on that CD, and I'm still partial to it. I can still remember sitting in the front seat of my mom's rental car up in Maine listening to this song over and over as we drove to my grandmother's beachhouse with Mallory and Shannon. Good times. 12. Out Of My Head - Fastball (2:32) This is a fun song. I'm not sure when I first heard it, or when I downloaded it, but it's along the same lines of some of the first songs that I ever downloaded on my computer ("The Way" by Fastball was definitely up there in the first 5 or so), which I listened to over and over until I had enough music to not run through all of them in an hour or two. 13. Runaround - Blues Traveler (4:39) Another song that is just generally fun. I'm not really sure what else I can say about it. 14. I Fought The Law - Green Day (2:42) This is a pretty new song, as far as I know. I think Max was the one who introduced me to it, and I'm a fan. I like it more than the original, even. Those boys know how to harmonize, which is always a good way to make me a fan (see: B*Witched, Blink 182 (below), and many others for more examples of this). 15. Aliens Exist - Blink 182 (3:13) I have one Blink 182 CD (Enema of the State), and while this song was never one of their singles, I think it was my favorite on it. It's a fun idea, and they also do a really nice with harmonizing on a few of the songs that just make me happy every time I hear them. What can I say? I'm a sucker for harmonizing. 16. Graceland - Paul Simon (4:51) Graceland was a CD that my mother has played for as long as I can remember (until my sister stole the CD and took it to school, that is *glares*). It's an amazing CD in general, and this song rocks. If you've never heard this CD, you're a heathen and you should go remedy this. Go! 17. Undenied - Portishead (4:24) A calmer song than many of the ones just preceding it, but Portishead is such a cool group that there was no way in hell I couldn't include them. This song rocks. They rock. I remember Vanessa freaking out about the fact that we were starting to listen to the same music and saying "Just don't listen to Portishead when I'm around!" I certainly hope she blushes when she reads this and remembers that phase. Of course, I would be posessive of Portishead too, so... 18. Anna Begins - Counting Crows (4:31) Counting Crows is one of my favorite bands, and this was one of their first songs that I loved. There are many more, of course, but I always liked this one. It's bittersweet, but excellent. I've always been a sucker for romantic, but sad things. 19. River Valley - Moxy Früvous (3:27) This is another group that my mother introduced me to when I was very young. Moxy Früvous is a very cool band (right, Jonathan? You know you're glad I introduced you to them), and this is the very first song on my favorite CD of theirs, so in some ways it's what I first think of when I think of them. Since we used to play this CD so often, the songs have kind of melded into each other so that when I finish listening to one, I can already hear the next one on the CD start, even if it doesn't. It's still a little jarring to hear this song and not hear "Stuck in the 90s" after it. 20. It Wasn't Me - Shaggy (3:47) This song is amusing as hell, but I think I have it on here because it makes me think of my brother Nick more than anything. Let's just say that sometimes I call him "Shaggy" because of this song, and leave it at that. 21. No Angel - Dido (3:55) I love Dido. I really do. She has a beautiful voice, and lovely arrangements. Her first CD, No Angel, was always one that my sister and I could always agree upon listening to, which helped prevent many a world-war over the years. 22. Only Happy When it Rains - Garbage (3:56) Garbage is a fun band. This is a fun song. What mix is hurt by tossing in a little Garbage? 23. Return Of The Phantom Stranger - Rob Zombie (4:31) Every time I hear this song I can't help but just get into it. It's just... fun. I like. 24. El Tango De Roxanne - Jacek Koman and Ewan McGregor (4:43) I've become somewhat obsessed with this song over the past few months since I first saw Moulin Rouge. The main song ("the Roxanne part", as I call it) is nice enough, but I just adore the background part by Ewan McGregor. I'm addicted to it. 25. I Shall Believe - Sheryl Crow (5:34) This song is beautiful. I like Sheryn Crow's music, but this one has always stuck out as beautiful to me. And it's just so heartbreaking (we all know I'm a sucker for that. I seem to be a sucker for a lot of things). Of course, in part that's because of an outside association I have, but that's a different matter. 26. Dark Angel - Blue Rodeo and Sarah McLachlan (5:16) Sarah McLachlan is another artist that I call "a favorite", and while this isn't one of her traditional songs, it's beautiful enough for me to use it for her. This is a nice calming song which is good for the end of a CD, in my opinion. Everyone we hear here (not that I really know much about Blue Rodeo except that they sing here) have beautiful voices, and use them wonderfully. And (in true copying-MacKenzie fashion), here's the unannotated copy: 1. Every Morning - Sugar Ray (3:45) 2. Let Me In - Save Ferris (6:14) 3. I Know - Fiona Apple (4:55) 4. Zombie - Cranberries (5:06) 5. Almost Blue - Gwen Stefani (2:59) 6. Beautiful - Christina Aquilera (3:58) 7. Everything in its Right Place - Radiohead (4:09) 8. Thank You - Alanis Morissette (4:18) 9. Hailie's Song - Eminem (5:23) 10. Gangsta's Paradise - Coolio (4:01) 11. Like The Rose - B*Witched (3:56) 12. Out Of My Head - Fastball (2:32) 13. Runaround - Blues Traveler (4:39) 14. I Fought The Law - Green Day (2:42) 15. Aliens Exist - Blink 182 (3:13) 16. Graceland - Paul Simon (4:51) 17. Undenied - Portishead (4:24) 18. Anna Begins - Counting Crows (4:31) 19. River Valley - Moxy Früvous (3:27) 20. It Wasn't Me - Shaggy (3:47) 21. No Angel - Dido (3:55) 22. Only Happy When it Rains - Garbage (3:56) 23. Return Of The Phantom Stranger - Rob Zombie (4:31) 24. El Tango De Roxanne - Jacek Koman and Ewan McGregor (4:43) 25. I Shall Believe - Sheryl Crow (5:34) 26. Dark Angel Blue Rodeo and Sarah McLachlan (5:16) total run time: 1:50:45

Tonight my mother and I watched urlLink Iron Jawed Angels , which we had taped a while ago on HBO. It was actually pretty good, notwithstanding some rather anachronistic actions from the leading ladies (even for forward thinkers of their time, it wasn't appropriate behavior for the early 1900s) and extremely modern musical choices. 'What is it about?' you ask? Well, it's telling the tale of the women's suffrage movement over the 6 or 7 years before the amendment was ratified. Hillary Swank was Alice Paul, Frances O'Connor was Lucy Burns, and Anjelica Houston was Carrie Chapman Catt (although I think my favorite was Julia Ormond as Inez Millholland). *shrug* I feel like I should have more to say about it, but that's all I can think of at the moment. Oh, and last night we finished watching urlLink Angels in America . That was fantastic .

Alright, let's see if I can figure out anything to say about my trip. I warn you, this is probably going to be long and boring, since we all know I suck at leaving out silly details, but I'll do my best (that's a lie... I'm not even going to try. This is going to be an annoying level of detail... unless I get tired of typing it all out, of course). If you want to skip to the end, I'll add some general comments which might be a bit more interesting for most of you. I flew from SFO to London, Heathrow on Friday night, which is almost exactly 10 hours. The plane was a little delayed, and left about about 7:30pm (or something... probably a bit later than that), so we got into Heathrow around midday or so (their time). I slept for maybe 5 or 6 hours, I think. It was actually a pretty nice plane. It had the personal video things, so there were about 5 movies playing on a continuous loop (most of them sucked, though). I watched Once Upon a Time in Mexico (cool, but confusing) and slept, until about the time we landed. After we got through customs and such, I strided purposefully across the airport to the section where my next flight (to Leeds, which is in the north, whereas London is in the south) would be, which was about half a mile away or something (seriously). Once I got there, I got into line to check into my next flight, until I realized that you couldn't check in until about 2 1/2 hours before the flight took off, and mine wasn't until 10 that night. I got out of line and wandered around a bit, until I found this place to get some food. I ordered a sandwich (more so that I could sit down than because I was hungry), and chilled for a few hours. The sandwich itself was actually pretty gross... After reading for a few hours, and trying to get some code to compile for my CS class (it wouldn't), it was finally late enough for me to check in to my flight. I headed back to the check-in area, only to discover that the flight had been cancelled due to "technical difficulties"! As it turned out, the catering truck that was getting the food on the plane had crashed into it , which I guess you could call a technical difficulty... However, they had organized a deal with another company to fly us all to Manchester (kind of near Leeds), and then put us on a bus to Leeds airport. The next flight was only about 25 minutes later than my original one was, but the bus ride would take about an hour or an hour and a half. I dutifully called the person who was picking me up from Leeds to let him know about the time change, and then checked into my new flight. I then got some really gross Burger King (hard to imagine just how they could make such overly-processed food worse , but they succeeded) and worked on my stupid calculus work, which I had dutifully brought with me (I had to take notes on everything we learned all year - about 13 chapters worth, so I figured when better than while I'm travelling around with 10 hour flights and 9 hour layovers?) until the plane boarded. I remember there were these really amazingly ugly green chairs in the waiting area outside of the gate. They were kind of a neon green and probably were installed in the early-70s, if the color was supposed to be in style. The only odd thing about the flight was that when we were landing, the plane got about 50 feet (maybe less) from the ground, and then went back up again! It was pretty weird, and the pilot came on and said something about there being something on the runway (who can really understand what they say over the speaker system anyway?), but then we landed for real a few minutes later and it was fine. Of course, by this point it was about 11 or so, and I had only gotten 5 or 6 hours of sleep the night before, so I was kind of tired... and my luggage wasn't there. It turns out that the kind people of British Airways left it in Heathrow because they wanted a little extra fuel because of the headwind (although I didn't know this at the time... all I knew was that I didn't have any clothes). I dutifully filled out the little form they gave me, and trundled onto the bus. When we arrived at Leeds, I called to tell Dennis (the one picking me up) that I had arrived, and he said he would be there in half an hour. I then sat outside in the late, cold, rainy weather until he showed up (no clue why I didn't wait inside , except that I wasn't sure whether he was planning on parking or anything). He got there around 12:30, drove me home, and I went to bed and slept for 10 hours. The next day (it's Sunday by this point), my luggage still hadn't shown up like they said it would. So I gave Dennis all of the relevant information they had given me, and he spent the day tracking it down (god bless that man...). I basically just lounged about the house and such most of the afternoon, and chilled with Alex, the 23 year old son of the family (and he helped me get that damn code to compile). That afternoon, Anne-Marie (the mother) got back from her trip to Cambridge and mothered me a bit (which I was fine with). She's always been very nice. She was my mom's roommate at Stanford oh so long ago, and she and her husband moved to England a long time ago, and have 2 kids, Jennifer and Alex. I was crashing with them for the weekend because my sister (who was the one I had intended on visiting) was actually off with her water polo team for the weekend partying at the Isle of Mann. Anyway, Anne-Marie gave me some clothes to wear until my luggage arrived the next morning (thank you, Dennis), and all was well. Oh, and Alex and I seem to have similar taste in music, which we discovered as we compared collections and traded back and forth a bit between our laptops. He even uses a Mac! The next day my clothes had arrived, which was nice, and I walked into the main part of town (Ripon) with Anne-Marie and Alex to run some errand before Vanessa showed up mid-afternoonish. We had dinner, and then Alex took Vanessa and I to a local pub for this 'pub quiz' thing. We met some of his friends and had fun and such, and picked up some Chinese food to snack on when the pub closed at 11, and headed back to the house. All in all, a fun day. Tuesday morning, Anne-Marie and Dennis actually headed here to California to deal with her mother, who's in a nursing home in Los Gatos. Alex was going to play host for Vanessa and I, and take us to Richard III's castle that was nearby so we could play tourists, but he remembered that he actually had to go to a wine tasting for his job (he's a bartender), so instead he dropped us off in York and so we wandered about there for the day. We went to this crazy museum in a vague attempt to be good tourists, but it was so random that we just made fun of it instead. It had stuff like the bones of an old Dodo bird in the same room as a random old Teddy Bear and a meteorite. It also went into great detail about the history of some old Abby (St. Mary's) and had some dinosaur bones to boot! Overall, just an odd museum... After looking at it for a bit, we went shopping in the shambles, which was fun. Then we had some tea ("high tea") before getting on a bus back to Ripon, which followed a circuitous route about the countryside (we were half afraid that we were never going to get to Ripon and would have to call Alex and tell him we were "in some field"). There were lots of sheep ("are there? are there sheep?"). That night we went to a 'real' pub, and then when it closed we went to where Alex works and he made us some cocktails. Dear lord, that was... a night of alcohol. My stomach still churns when I think of some of those drinks. Anyway, then we headed home and eventually got to bed... The next day (Wednesday, I think) Vanessa and I headed to Sheffield to visit her new boyfriend, Tom, for the day. We took the train out there and met his mother and saw some baby pictures, before he frantically got us out of his house, and we wandered about the town. We played some team pool with Tom's friend Alex (miraculously, whatever team I was on won each time, although I didn't really help. I suck at pool.) and had some lunch before heading back to Tom's house to watch Mallrats. Tom's mother made us dinner (which was good), before Vanessa and I headed back to Ripon for the night. Tom seemed very nice (yes, Vanessa, that's all I can really think to say about him). Thursday, we headed over to Birmingham to visit another old friend of ours (well, more our mom's, since they worked together, but she's nice) who lives in England. We got in the trains in the early afternoon, and got there around 6 or so (they were pretty slow). We went out and got some Chinese food for dinner, and spent the rest of the evening just chatting, which was also fun. We talked quite a bit about school systems and accents, actually. Interesting stuff... Friday Vanessa and I took the train to Oxford and got in in early evening. We went out and had some really nice French food for dinner (my god, that was good stuff) and spent the rest of the evening chatting with one of her housemates, Dan. He and I got along fantastically, since we seemed to be rather similar in many of our tastes, etc. Saturday I took a bus to Heathrow, and got on the plane and came home. I got in around 5ish, and got home around 6:30. I collapsed in bed around 8, and slept for 12 hours. Overall, it was a fun trip, although I spent the majority of my time in places other than Oxford (which was where we thought I was going to be). My sister and I got along quite well, considering we're sisters, so that was nice. Also, the entire time I found myself very aware of my American accent (when we were in public), and was self-conscious enough to not speak much (odd, considering self-consciousness is not usually a problem for me...). Also, when I was speaking with people (Anne-Marie and I had quite a few interesting conversations) I was hyper-aware of my grammer, which seemed much worse than usual. I'm not sure what was going on there, but I definitely wasn't speaking very well... A fun time was had in general. And now that I've avoided my homework for an hour or so longer, I should probably get to work on that. *groan* Is it college yet?

Home again from foreign lands. So... I'm back. Hi! *waves tiredly* What time is it? 7 pm? 3 am? Somewhere in between? Damned if I know. I think I'm probably hovering somewhere over the middle of the Atlantic time-wise. Anyway, the trip was a lot of fun. I'll try to type up a real report of it later, but frankly I'm fucking tired right now. I just thought I'd let you all know I was alive or whatever.
Well, I'm heading off to the airport in an hour or so. I hope everyone else has (or has had) a fantastic spring break!

I think that's kinda cool. It's not the most surprising thing in the world, since both my mom and sister are O- too, but my dad's not so there was a chance I wouldn't be. I'm glad I am, though. It's cool. :)
One: I got my cap and gown today. Excitement! Coolness, no? Two: I put up some pictures from school, although more will be forthcoming. Feel free to peruse any or all of them at your leisure.

I just went with some friends of mine on the swim team to donate blood to the Stanford Blood people (I forget their official name), and it was a surprisingly fun experience. There were about 8 or so of us, so it took a while for them to get to everyone (even though a few people couldn't do it because their iron level was too low), and while I didn't know some people there, and I was nervous, it was still cool. Once I finally got in there, it took them a while to find a good vein (I think I have my mother to thank for that... hers move around or something). Once they did actually find one they liked, it turned out it was "deceptively deep", and so it only took me about 4 minutes to give the blood, which is kind of fast, although not outrageously so. The process itself wasn't too painful, either. I think the mild stinging in my arm right now is probably the worst of it, and I didn't feel dizzy or lightheaded or anything after I gave. I seem to be a natural. So now I get to wait a few weeks for them to mail me the thingy that lets me know what type blood I have, and hopefully go donate again in July when I get the chance.

I just put up the pictures from the get-together last night at Eric's house. There aren't too many, but I think a few are quite nice, personally (and I didn't even take most of them!). Speaking of which, I thought I'd just remind anyone who cares that if they want a higher-quality copy of any of these pictures for themselves, feel free to ask me. The pictures I have up here are about 1/6 the size of the originals, and thus they lost some detail, etc.

Eric was just over and we were being bored on my computer, and so we (I) decided to look up all of the nicknames of Elizabeth (since it has a lot ). We found urlLink a page with quite a few of them, although I think my personal favorites were definitely Elspeth (and a few variations thereof) and Erzsi. Sadly, however, all of them already seem to be taken as screen names, and that's no fun. So, who wants to call me one of those now?

Well, I'm working on making my blog more presentable and blog-like, aka: actually have titles for my posts, and use their nifty new comment system. I have the titles working, as you see, but at the moment I'm not in the mood to attack my template code without my father around to fix whatever I screw up, especially since we've already made a number of changes to it in the first place that I don't want screwed up (or else I would just change templates entirely... now there's a thought). Also, I'm too lazy (unlike urlLink some people ) to go back through all of my old posts to add titles, because frankly I don't think they're worth it.
I am so frustrated with my family right now; I cannot wait until college starts and I am on the opposite side of the country.

I just got my Big Packet of Info from MIT with everything I need to deal with between now and who know's when. While I'm excited (college!), I'm also nervous, and not looking forward to all of this crap I have to deal with. And the decisions to make! Oh, god, the decisions! Oh, and I can now recieve email on my cellphone (in theory, I admit I haven't actually tested it out yet), which is exciting. The address is myfirstname.cell@mylastname.org (actual address changed as to avoid the possibility of spam... but you're intelligent people, so you should be able to figure it out. If you can't, contact me and I'll explain it to you and mock you at the same time).

You know what sucks? When you have to write an essay, but you're in such the wrong frame of mind, that to get each sentence out is like slamming your brain against some metaphorical wall -- slamming it HARD. And if you don't slam it hard enough, it's not enough to get the sentence out, and you'll have to do it again.

I don't think of myself as someone who's good with "heart to hearts". I mean, what the hell are you supposed to say when someone's having enough trouble with something in his/her life to talk to you about it? Clearly there's no easy solution, because if there were then it wouldn't be a problem, and usually it's something that he/she is going to have to decide for him/herself. From what I can see, the most you can really do is listen to them, and try to help them organize their thoughts. I don't approve of trying to make up people's minds for them, so what else can you really do? God, I suck at this.

I just spent the evening with a few of my cousins over at SBC Park, watching the Giants play the Red Sox. It was a total blast, and I think I am now officially a Red Sox fan (and not just because they won 14-9). There was a ridiculous number of home runs throughout the evening (6 or 7, I think), and for some reason the section where we were sitting had an inordinate number of Sox fans as well (our theory was that it was becuase all the Giants fans had season tickets and, as such, better seats). There was even a taste of Fenway park with fights erupting and an obnoxious man saying the same things over and over again! Now I'm determined to go see them play at Fenway, but I might take my big hulky cousin Mike to protect me. Oh, and there are pictures forthcoming. I'm just uploading them now, though, so it may take a while.

I don't care if it's been panned by the critics, or that it has a plot hole you could drive... the state of Texas through, The Stepford Wives was hilarious. I've seen it twice already, and it was just as funny the second time. I want to marry Roger (the gay man), or at least have his children. And if I could, I would get the "book club" scene and watch it a few more times, just for good measure. Go see it. Really.

My elementary school, El Carmelo, is the only one that got split between Paly and Gunn, so about half of the people I knew back then I haven't seen in 7 years. However, some people organized a little reunion for us, which was today in Mitchell Park. I took pictures (duh), which I just put up online. Peruse them at your leisure, if you so desire.

This is surreal. I still don't think it's sunk in yet. I mean, it's hard to imagine that I probably won't see a large portion of my classmates... ever again. Except maybe at high school reunions. Wow. That's a weird thought too. I've decided that there are too many wonderful people who go/went to school at Paly. I mean, not only do I have some amazingly wonderful friends (some of whom I'm so lucky to have gotten to know better this year), but also there are a lot of people out there that I wish that I had gotten to know. There was just never enough time to spend time with all of them. Anyway, now that it sounds like I just signed someone's yearbook, I should go to bed. Grad night is over, and the next step of life is that much closer. I miss everyone already!

Or have any of you noticed that I haven't been online much recently? That would be because the internet connection at my mother's house has died. DIED! It's awful. Anyway, I'm over at my dad's for an hour or so tonight to check my email and the like, but I don't have time to get online. Hopefully I'll be back on on Thursday night, since tomorrow is graduation. Oh, and I finished posting all of the pictures from the end of school, so go take a peek. Also, I'm working on putting up the pictures from the senior picnic, so keep an eye out for those as well.
I have the spine of a jellyfish.

Harmony: "You know, I really wish we could have got to know each other better." Willow: "Me, too." Harmony: "I mean, you're so smart. I always wanted to be like that." Willow: "Thanks, you're so sweet!" Harmony: "I hope we don't lose touch." Willow: "No, we'll hang out. Oh, I'm gonna miss her." Buffy: "Don't you hate her?" Willow: "Yes, with a fiery vengeance. She picked on me for 10 years. The vacuous tramp. It's like a sickness, Buffy. I'm just missing everything. I miss P.E.!" This has been my basic frame of mind the last few days in particular, minus the hating people part. Or the missing of P.E. And now classes are officially over, and all that's left are Baccalaureate, Senior picnic, and the actual graduation. I don't think it's really sunk in yet, though. I mean, I'm already missing everyone because I know I probably won't see most of them much (if ever) again, and that sucks because everyone is really cool. On the other hand, I don't think it's really sunk in yet that I'm not going to be going back to school at Paly next year. It's hard to imagine what college will be like, which I think adds to the feeling of detatchment. On a side note, I've been spending the last few days scrambling to put together the present my chem class gave to our teacher. I'm actually rather pleased by the outcome, which is good since I dedicated more than a few hours to make it. The "it" to which I refer, of course, is a "Men of Chemistry" calendar, featuring all of the guys in our class. Copies of the pictures are posted in my pictures section, so go check 'em out.

I just got my wisdom teeth taken out today. At the moment my jaw is still completely numb, so I don't know how much this is going to suck. Being knocked out for it was quite an interesting experience, though. Besides the fact that they nearly couldn't find a vein to get the IV into (that's a problem with me and my veins...), it went just fine. About 30 seconds after they put it in, I was out for the count. The next thing I knew, I was being walked into their recuperation area, where I stayed for I don't know how long (probably not more than about 15 minutes, actually), and then I was driven home by my mom (I have absolutely no memory of this after walking to the car, but I got home so it must have happened). After that, I basically fell asleep on the couch after about 5 minutes or so (maybe less) and I didn't wake up for about 3 hours. I seem to have completely recovered from whatever drug they used to knock me out, and now I just have the fun-filled job of entertaining myself without being able to talk. Anyway, if anyone calls for me the next time I see you I'll smack you.

So today I went with my sister while she got her hair cut to keep her friend Ria company and possibly get a "consultation" for a haircut of my own. (This is part of why my hair grows so long -- it's a huge thing whenever I do get it cut. It's kind of a horrible cycle, of course, but that's beside the point.) Anyway, while I was there one of the women was like, "oh, I can cut it now" so I got it cut. It was rather quick and painless, actually, which is just how I like it. Anyway, it's about shoulder length now, and the woman straightened it (which is, in a way, too weird for words) so it's pretty radically different. I'll get pictures up at some point, but I have to take them first.

So I just took urlLink this quiz and it actually had some interesting results so I thought I'd post it here. I have no idea whether it's really true, though. You are an SECL --Sober Emotional Constructive Leader. This makes you a politician . You cut deals, you change minds, you make things happen. You would prefer to be liked than respected, but generally people react to you with both. You are very sensitive to criticism, since your entire business is making people happy. At times your commitment to the happiness of other people can cut into the happiness of you and your loved ones. This is very demanding on those close to you, who may feel neglected. Slowly, you will learn to set your own agenda--including time to yourself. You are gregarious, friendly, charming and charismatic. You like animals, sports, and beautiful cars. You wear understated gold jewelry and have secret bad habits, like chewing your fingers and fidgeting. You are very difficult to dislike.
